posts.name: Bartek
posts.cooked:
Hi! Our team has built an arm that has 180degrees of movement (front to back axis). We need to program it to keep the angle that we want (preferably pre-programmed angle states). We wanted to do it by PID and encoder. I calculated the ratios and have accurate angle of arm itself but when testing PID to setPoint it to 15deg it flew all the way back and slammed floor. The encoder values were good i think. The arm is somewhat heavy but motors have more than enough power to power it. (20% is fast enough for moving it)

I need help with programming it to angle states and making it keep angle with no driver input.  I’m kinda worried with testing it, bcs i dont want to slam it again. If you know some good way to protect it when tesing that would help.

(the code is here: GitHub - SpiceGears/FRC-2023 at develop develop branch is failed pid attempt, and main is working code on simple “can power when encoder is not over the top”)

Thanks in advance!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 5883 Software Mentor | FGC Team Poland Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 5883 Software Mentor | FGC Team Poland Mentor

posts.cooked:
Physical protection… tape a pool noodle to it.

Coding protection…  use a clamping function to make sure you limit it while tuning it.  As you get dialed in relax the clamp.

This based on the WPILIB arm example.

posts.name: Bartek
posts.cooked:
Ok, I haven’t really worked with feedforward before, and i didn’t do TrapeziodProfile thingy for setpoint and constraints, i just had simple angles of arm.

How do I find the velocity and all of the kS kV kA values for feedforward? And what is this double output ? And if i implement it and change the setpoint going into this function, will the arm will smoothly translate to new setpoint? I don’t understand the code in super()

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 5883 Software Mentor | FGC Team Poland Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 5883 Software Mentor | FGC Team Poland Mentor

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
First of all, set kI to 0. That alone probably caused what you saw due to integral windup if you changed your setpoint directly from 0 to 180 or whatever.

Feedforward is the correct answer.  You can use the ArmFeedForward class in WPILib (this is a direct link, but i highly recommend reading the whole page).  You can get the necessary constants (kG, kS, kV) empirically, or by using sysID (which will also give you kA)

link_counts.title: Feedforward Control in WPILib — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
Introduction to System Identification — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked:
elobenc:

And what is this double output ?

In the example it is the result of the profiled (trapezoid) PID Controller.

A trapezoid profile allows you to control the maximum velocity and acceleration of the output from the PID .   You don’t need to do it… you can control the maximum with the clamp too.  However, the trapezoid profile allows “smooth” increase in velocity of your arm.

posts.name: Tom Winter
posts.cooked: It is also possible that your motor or your encoder are inverted so that the feedback is actively causing the error to get worse, instead of better.  Before running your feedback loop, trying running your motor with positive power and ensure that the encoder readings are going up, not down.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
elobenc:

(Kg isnt going to be 9.81, it would be too easy right?)

No; you can tell this because the units would not make any sense.  That equation needs to yield volts. The acceleration of gravity has units of meters per second squared.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: You will have to either use manual calculation, an online calculator like ReCalc, or physical test routines to figure out the relevant gains.  I suggest doing something a bit more precise than tapping on a joystick - do you have working telemetry so you can read the applied voltage on your dashboard?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
elobenc:

I’m not sure about the weight and CoM distance and efficiency (andymark toughbox → chain reduction)

Those are what really determine your gains, so if you’re not sure about those your gains probably won’t be correct.  You should try to measure them as accurately as possible.

Efficiency is usually well-estimated by a 10% loss per reduction stage (a little less for gears/belt, a little more for chain).

posts.name: Mika Okamoto
posts.cooked: Are you logging your encoders values? Before we run PID we always log our encoders and check they move to desired values when we move the subsystem manually (to rule out incorrect gear ratio entered in code, encoders inverted, etc).

posts.name: Bartek
posts.cooked: yeah, that time it wasnt encoders reading fault, because they were showing good angle. I think it was due to kI value.

accepted_answer.excerpt:
Tests for today completed. I had a call with programmers and programmers mentor, and the mistake happened to be: 
Overriding parent periodic() function. When i was writing the code for my subsystem I copied the constructor, but didnt delete my periodic override. I didnt knew it wasnt supposed to be …
